byline.contributor: Monica Davey reported from Chicago, and Timothy Williams from New York. Mitch Smith and Brent McDonald contributed reporting from Chicago.
byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

abstract: Chicago police have record of brutality going back decades, with officers shooting and killing 70 people, most of them black, in five-year period ending in 2014, yet they are known for issuing little or no punishment to their own; city has spent more than $500 million settling police cases since 2004.
lead_paragraph: The city spent more than $500 million settling police cases since 2004, but a vast majority of complaints against the police still do not result in discipline.

headline.main: Chicago Pays Millions but Punishes Few in Killings by Police
headline.print_headline: Chicago Pays, While Few Officers Do, in Killings

snippet: The city spent more than $500 million settling police cases since 2004, but a vast majority of complaints against the police still do not result in discipline.
